prompt: What does it mean for a logical system to be COMPLETE?
options: Every valid argument can be proven
The system has all possible rules
hint: Completeness is about the proof system being able to prove all true things.
explanation: Completeness: If ⊨ φ (φ is valid) then ⊢ φ (φ is provable). Every truth can be proven. Complete systems miss nothing - if it's true, you can prove it. First-order logic is complete (Gödel 1929).
visual_concept: Completeness: Everything inside the 'true' circle is also inside the 'provable' circle. No truths escape our proof system.
